section.text: Yeah, good morning. Arun Jayaram from J.P. Morgan.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Arun Jayaram", "section_number": 1, "uuid": "92408598-4f47-4293-a729-d3c4325679ba", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 2, "uuid": "b7fca624-8b23-4220-a562-177d7517bea2", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Good morning, guys. John, I know you guys are pretty knee-deep in your planning and budgeting process, but I was wondering if you could offer any soft guidance commentary for 2023 as we think about volumes and capex and what is obviously a little bit more of an inflationary environment, particularly offshore.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Arun Jayaram", "section_number": 3, "uuid": "720abe50-019f-4bb7-827f-1ea78b40dd95", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: Sure, Arun. Thanks for the question. As usual, we will provide, to your point, our 2023 capital guidance in January, but I'll try to give you some high-level information now, compared to 2022. So, if we're going to start with Guyana, in 2022, we have $1 billion of development spend. And as you know, that includes two projects Payara and Yellowtail. So in 2023, we will continue spending on Payara and Yellowtail, but we will add, subject to government approval, a third development project at Uaru, and to a lesser amount, a gas to energy project as well. So while the Uaru project is going to have industry leading returns in a low cost-to-supply, the cost of the Uaru project, as you mentioned, will be higher, reflecting the current market conditions as well as additional scope to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. So with that, we currently expect our Guyana spend to increase by approximately $500 million to $700 million in 2023. So you know, the midpoint of that would be going up from $1 billion to $1.6 billion.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "e1a2adda-97c8-40f5-9658-e1d3580af339", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: In the Bakken, we are spending approximately $850 million this year and we added a fourth rig later in the year. So we expect an additional $250 million of spend in 2023, reflecting a full year of a four-rig program. And that four rig program as well as the expected industry inflation drives that $250 million increase there in the Bakken.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "e1a2adda-97c8-40f5-9658-e1d3580af339", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: In the Gulf of Mexico, we are still finalizing our 2023 program, but we do see the potential for two well tiebacks and also one hub class exploration opportunity. So with that, it's approximately $150 million increase in the Gulf of Mexico. So therefore, adding those up, taking the midpoint of the Guyana number, we expect our 2023 capital exploratory expanded, again it's preliminary, to be approximately $3.7 billion or about $1 billion more than 2022.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 4, "uuid": "e1a2adda-97c8-40f5-9658-e1d3580af339", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Great. And, any thoughts on just overall volumes, or too premature at this point?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Arun Jayaram", "section_number": 5, "uuid": "ab50aa36-2640-4f3d-bb35-6d288344e8de", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: It is premature at this point. I mean, again, think about us from a longer term standpoint of production growth. We've seen that we can grow our topline production growth, and it's just an output of the great opportunities that we have in Guyana, that over the long term, we can grow at greater it than 10%. So, just think about, in 2024 now, as Greg mentioned earlier, we will get the Bakken to 200,000 barrels a day, and then we'll have Pyara on as well. So that's going to add another 50,000 to 55,000 barrels. So, write that, add those two together, you're almost up 25% absolute from where we are right now. So again, as we move into next year, we'll give that production guide early in the year, but the growth is going to be lumpy, basically when the FPSOs come online. So, that's how you should think about it as we move into next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 6, "uuid": "1471373b-0a61-41a1-8910-8b76c11a48b4", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Great. And just my follow up, I wanted to I'm getting some buyside queries on Exxon's release today and maybe you could just help clarify, they mentioned in their release that they expect Guyana's oil productive capacity to be more than 1 million barrels by the end of the decade. John, today you mentioned 6 FPSOs by 2027, which is in line with the consortium's previous outlook. Anything in that comment on Exxon's release that you could kind of clarify?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Arun Jayaram", "section_number": 7, "uuid": "a0712034-b31d-4314-a660-0ab43991c007", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: No, you'll have to ask Exxon about that. But our comment about by '27 having productive capacity growth of over 1 million barrels of oil per day, that's very consistent with what Exxon has said the last several years, and that's correct outlook.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 8, "uuid": "81166939-e279-4c9b-a29a-f983b4a5b97e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Okay, great. Probably just semantics. Thanks a lot, John.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Arun Jayaram", "section_number": 9, "uuid": "598f6f93-4ef5-466a-a778-e34465d79567", "speaker_title": "Analyst at J.P. Morgan"}

section.text: I love the pronunciation. Good morning, everybody.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Leggate", "section_number": 11, "uuid": "0c2e01c3-9f24-4141-9130-747c84484553", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lunch"}

section.text: Good morning, Doug.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 12, "uuid": "66baf21d-ead8-4f0b-ae1c-b10a3fb5e4a1", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: John, I guess, I would like to -- sorry to be up on this last point that Arun mentioned, but I know I've asked you and I've asked Exxon this before and who has listened, they know that Exxon's answer is, they're basically being conservative, but tell me why with loan [Indecipherable] that you're clearly going to have in these boats. The production capacity of an additional 5 and 6 to 20 doesn't get you close to 1.3. Over 1 million just seems to me -- is getting a bit old, pardon the expression, but it looks to us, at least 30% over that with what you've got line of sight. Why is that not right?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Leggate", "section_number": 13, "uuid": "31c491ed-85b4-4d9b-84c5-13c261e60399", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lunch"}

section.text: Doug, I think the 2027 number 6 FPSOs and at least 1 million barrels a day of gross production is a good number, it's a conservative number, and is there some upside to that? Yes, there certainly is.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 14, "uuid": "f97cdba6-f9f0-4fe8-a6b0-2bcdb758b1dc", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Is my math wrong?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Leggate", "section_number": 15, "uuid": "6967ab86-543d-4fb6-95de-dc96355054ac", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lunch"}

section.text: No. Well, as opposed to talk to your math, let's talk about our math. We're saying 1 million barrels a day, 6 FPSOs, 2027, there's upside to that number.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 16, "uuid": "c65317a1-f57a-4885-9f80-4c6f7994af81", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Okay, alright. Sorry to press. Alright, my follow-up is as you look into -- John's obviously walked through the capex story, obviously the the cash -- the recovery of the cash flow capex in Guyana, makes a lot of that, obviously just somewhat to the mute to the overall cash return story, I guess, given how quickly you get the money back. So I guess my question is that the 75% of free cash flow target, you're clearly lagging that this year. What can we expect by way of an inflection in cash returns in 2023 at [Indecipherable] current strip.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Leggate", "section_number": 17, "uuid": "fa9dec5b-c621-4bc5-8930-de9003947844", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lunch"}

section.text: Hey, Doug, thanks for the question. It's an excellent one. As we look to 2023, our financial priorities remain first, to invest in our high return opportunities especially in Guyana and Bakken that John talked about, the $3.7 billion capital program. Second, to maintain a strong cash position and balance sheet to ensure that we can fund these high return opportunities and investments through the cycle. Then, we would give strong consideration next year to further increasing our regular dividend. And then following that, in line with the capital return program where we have committed to returning the remainder of our free cash flow up to 75% through share repurchases, and similar to this year, we have the flexibility to return in excess of 75%, you'll recall at the end of the quarter we had $2.38 billion of cash on the balance sheet. So we have flexibility for next year. So depending upon market conditions, oil prices, financial prices, where the recession and the economic slowdown come out, we'll be positioned to increase our return of capital further, but that's going to be a decision that we'll make as we go into next year. First, to make sure that we can fund our high return programs, second, keep the strong balance sheet, third, increase the dividend and then anything left over as we go out, not just next year but in the years ahead, and we deliver increasing levels of free cash flow, we expect share repurchases will represent a growing proportion of our capital return program in the years ahead.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 18, "uuid": "585999ed-f43b-4f45-9d99-196273909672", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Sorry, John, just to be clear, you've got a debt maturity next year. How much is that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Leggate", "section_number": 19, "uuid": "a4afc430-4387-4b07-a070-43081d7bbf33", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lunch"}

section.text: It's actually in 2024, and it's $300 million, in 2024, and we do expect to...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 20, "uuid": "ce4be699-4cfb-4b1e-b229-442e45d10726", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: '24, got it.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Leggate", "section_number": 21, "uuid": "a1086e45-7819-4bff-9aaf-48506a02b555", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lunch"}

section.text: Yeah. Hey, Doug, I just want to make sure what you said earlier because this year, we are actually returning more than our 75% in our framework. So just remember, our framework, we did our debt reduction of $500 million and as John mentioned, our framework has the flexibility when oil prices are strong, to do more than 75%. And that's what we are doing this year. As John mentioned, we'll complete the $310 million in the fourth quarter. So again, we have that flexibility to stay strong, and as John said, depending on market conditions, we'll do 75% or more. We'll see.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 22, "uuid": "b409be0e-cc38-4311-9a78-06529d36f860", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Thanks so much, guys.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Doug Leggate", "section_number": 23, "uuid": "76b432f7-2865-46cd-bc99-15b406283391", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bank of America Merrill Lunch"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 25, "uuid": "c01cd956-9098-4308-b417-d3016cacb52c", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 26, "uuid": "352a7f0b-4479-454e-b75a-26ec1de0eccd", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Thank goodness for easy-to-pronounce names. Could -- I was wondering if I could ask Greg a couple on exploration. On one, it seem that you're got a success at Yarrow and Banjo-1. It sounds like it wasn't -- our recollection was that this was testing through the inboard oil play to the southeast. Could you maybe talk about a little bit more things that you're able in terms of those two, and what was confirmed and what wasn't, and what we should take away from that?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 27, "uuid": "b918f921-de7f-46b6-9d4e-b31f0eef27e7", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Yeah, sure. So, first of all, I would say the inboard oil play has been very successful because we've had four discoveries in the area. So recall Barreleye had 230 feet of high quality pay, Seabob had had 131 feet of high quality pay as we announced this morning, Yarrow had 75 feet of high quality pay, and finally Lucanani had 115 feet of high quality pay. So all of those will help to underpin a future development. And even though Banjo was dry, it had non-commercial qualities of -- quantities of hydrocarbons, it had hydrocarbons that went through it, we've got more wells to drill in that area.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "7a27bfbc-6676-4d42-8316-cbeaa48b0e1f", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: So if I step back and say four successes, one non-commercial and more to come, I still feel very optimistic about the inboard play. And also, I think it's important to know that Banjo was the western most prospect that we drilled in that inboard play as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 28, "uuid": "7a27bfbc-6676-4d42-8316-cbeaa48b0e1f", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: That's helpful. And maybe, Greg. I mean this whole semantics around 1 million barrels or the 6 boats or the 10 boats or whatever it may be, could you maybe -- at what point should we be thinking that we get more clarity in terms of the length of plateau versus additional boats? Is this something that we're going to be get some additional clarity in the next 12, 24 months, or is this a longer than as we kind of see how reservoirs react and production? But it seems to us that that's the. -- as we think about recovering...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 29, "uuid": "dd2eb7d1-e5cc-4d05-aee8-50b3dddd9b55", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Sure...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 30, "uuid": "3912b1c3-958f-4f74-bfe9-63ae64f010fb", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: 11 plus billion barrels, those are kind of the two variables.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 31, "uuid": "f784cfaa-1c7f-4a19-8acc-e7ff28ad1839", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Yes, Steve, I want Greg to answer that but you have the clarity what production's going to be. It's a gross 1 million barrels a day at least, in 2027. I think that's really important so people don't get confused by other releases. That is the number, and there's upside to that. Now, Greg can talk more about tiebacks and plateaus, but that 1 million barrels a day is very good number that people should use in terms of having clarity and visibility of the production and growth trajectory.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 32, "uuid": "f6c59d50-e864-4f1c-bc6f-be750bd69b70", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Okay.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 33, "uuid": "b1e527b5-325a-4453-afe3-993799b21ae5", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: This is Greg. So, I think the plateau rates or length, I should say, are going to vary by vessel. However, given the high resource density and the the potential for near field tiebacks and that's in both the Upper Campanian and the deeper plays, because remember, the deep play underlies the shallower Upper Campanian reservoirs, so we expect to see these production plateaus remain for a longer period than what would be typical for other deepwater development. So, I'm pretty optimistic about the length of the plateaus. But again, each one will be bespoke based upon the reservoir density in and around each vessel.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 34, "uuid": "db0ca02a-ac29-4eca-bfef-d9639755f02a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Stephen Richardson", "section_number": 35, "uuid": "330a3f58-5d42-4331-87f8-2265317fdf83", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Evercore ISI"}

section.text: Good morning, team. First question is around...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neil Mehta", "section_number": 37, "uuid": "8e76228d-86e7-49de-897b-9cc9c3074dc0", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 38, "uuid": "8e932bff-e1ba-47a9-a2a0-3b8e63334293", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Good morning, John. First question is around the Bakken. Really good quarter for you guys here, after some weather issues earlier this year. Can you just refresh us on how we should be thinking about the trajectory in the Bakken in '23 and then as you get into '24 as well?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neil Mehta", "section_number": 39, "uuid": "46dcec8c-0c7d-4317-ac08-5eae456c4e11", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Sure. So, we guided 165,000 to 170,000 In the fourth quarter of this year, and that really reflects a couple of things. One is, most of the wells are going to be completed at the back-end of the quarter. We also looked at our historic, kind of weather performance in the fourth quarter, and we increased our contingency a little bit in the fourth quarter to reflect that. If you think about where we're headed in the Bakken, with the four rigs, that's going to allow us to increase production to about 200,000 barrels a day in 2024. And with our extensive inventory of high return wells, we expect to hold this plateau for nearly a decade and then generate significant free cash flow. And during that period of time, you can assume that the oil percentage at the well head is going to be broadly flat at around that 65%. So you can almost -- endpoint this year and pretty much straight line to the end of 2024, assuming the end of 2024 would be 200,000. And that will give you a reasonable approximation of what the trajectory will be.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 40, "uuid": "85dbfc73-68f8-4401-9d50-73f4bd89d857", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: All right, that's good color here. And then John, if I could ask you to step back and talk about your view on the macro -- you always have a good read on the oil markets. Just your perspective on where we are in terms of the rebalancing as you go into 2023, and how that feeds into your framework around hedging given the backwardation in the curve?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neil Mehta", "section_number": 41, "uuid": "ec183567-4aed-4bcd-b926-d1a281ee8e59", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yeah, I'll give some remarks on -- further detail on how we see the oil market and John Rielly will talk about our hedging. Look, the impact of high interest rates, strong dollar, inflation obviously is being felt in the financial markets. You know better than anybody. From your perspective, it's already being felt, not only in the financial markets and the pullback, but also in certain parts of the economy. But I have to say, even though we've seen a slowing of demand in China and in Europe overall, global oil demand continues to be pretty resilient, and we're not seeing a major impact from inflation and the high dollar in oil demand itself. And in fact, as we look out to next year between China reopening its economy and continuing to increase overall global air travel, we see upside to current demands globally of 1 million -- 100 million barrels are going up 1 million barrels a day next year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "09040d00-5449-4b83-b4b4-4a533185fc2f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: I don't think if there is a pullback in the economy where it does affect oil demand, I don't think it's going to be anywhere near what it was during the world financial crisis which was upwards of 2 million barrels a day. But I think part of what's going on here, there's been a slow but steady increase in demand recovering from COVID, and we haven't completed that recovery yet, and that's the major reason oil demand, we think, as you go into next year, will go up, at least 1 million barrels a day from the 100 million a day right now.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "09040d00-5449-4b83-b4b4-4a533185fc2f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: The risk, I think, is to the upside, what's going to happen with Russia oil supply, what's gonna happen with Russia gas supply, how do we get through the winter, I think -- how cold is the winter, that, if anything, could increase that 1 million barrels a day that I just talked about. As you know, there's oil substitution for gas supply industrially, some residential, commercial, both in Europe and Asia, obviously on the electricity side. How much that's fuel substitution, remains to be seen as well.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "09040d00-5449-4b83-b4b4-4a533185fc2f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: So we see the market, if anything, having strengthening impact tailwinds going into the winter, and as such, I'd say there is more upside to the price from where we are now than there is downside. But with that sort of as a backdrop, John, how about our hedging?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 4, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 42, "uuid": "09040d00-5449-4b83-b4b4-4a533185fc2f", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Sure. So with that backdrop, Neil you know what we do is we use put options for our hedging strategy. And with all the variables that John just mentioned and the time value here, the volatility levels, right now putting on the puts would be too expensive. So we do plan to get to similar level of hedge protection that we had this year.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "73bb6929-02a1-4c8f-84a8-7ecaee874ff7", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Now, we will continue to watch the market, we'll try to get some on in fourth quarter, but it could be early next year that we get these hedges on. So you should expect us to get to a similar hedge position on. It will just be a matter of timing, when we do it, and again just would put options.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 43, "uuid": "73bb6929-02a1-4c8f-84a8-7ecaee874ff7", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: And again, to underline what John said, that's to protect the downside and still give our shareholders the benefit of the upside.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 44, "uuid": "52bbf86d-c489-409d-9a07-e4cddaae082e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Makes a lot of sense. Thank you, both.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Neil Mehta", "section_number": 45, "uuid": "7d22d420-7105-4b48-b398-75d0db83204d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Goldman Sachs"}

section.text: Yeah, good morning. I'm going to come back, I guess, a little bit on the capex. I know you're hesitant to get any more than what you've had, but I'm just a little curious as you look across the various regions you operate onshore U.S., offshore U.S. in Guyana, like how much of, when you look out, you can say is fairly well committed or contracted, signed, where there's not a lot of risk of a surprise as we think about '23 on the capex front? The underlying inflation that we're just kind of seeing everywhere.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Roger Read", "section_number": 47, "uuid": "3a6cf8ec-ea9c-4004-add8-324334473257", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Yeah. So on the inflation, like our competitors, we're seeing upward pressure across both our onshore and offshore businesses and steel prices, labor costs, rig rates. So, let's talk about the Bakken first. Regarding the Bakken, now what we've seen this year, the industry is seeing overall inflation of 15% to 20% versus 2021. However, as you know, our teams have been able to reduce this to 8.5%. And we've done that through lean manufacturing, strategic contracting and technology, and that's enabled us to deliver that D&C cost to $6.3 million per well in 2022. So, our net inflation has been about the half of what the industry has seen in the Bakken, if you will.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "08f03e1a-b259-4b55-a868-11a82ca76ec3", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Now if we look at 2023, in broad terms, we're anticipating a further 15% to 20% inflation in the oil country tubular goods. Even though steel prices are moderating, the mills are still at capacity, and demand is very strong. We're also expecting 15% to 20% potentially in drilling rigs, and 5% to 10% inflation in frac spreads, frac sand and labor. So, that kind of gives you an idea.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "08f03e1a-b259-4b55-a868-11a82ca76ec3", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Now, of course, we're working to mitigate some of these further increases and will guide well costs in the Bakken in January 2023 as usual. And recall in Guyana, the first four FPSOs are contracted and have limited exposure to inflation. I should add that operator has done an excellent job of offsetting any inflation in oil country tubular goods et cetera through the efficiency gains that they've realized in Guyana. As already mentioned the Uaru FPSO cost is going to reflect current market conditions as well as scope changes, and will give an update on Uaru once the project has been approved and sanction, but it will still be world-class, still have world-class breakevens.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 48, "uuid": "08f03e1a-b259-4b55-a868-11a82ca76ec3", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Yeah, It's certainly something to watch down there. And the only other question I had is related to Guyana is, has there been any update, any change to the thoughts of gas development down there long term? I mean I know we have the pipeline to the onshore, but anything else as you had these additional discoveries and as you're thinking about 2027 period with 6 FPSOs? No, I think in the short-term, it's all about the gas gas pipeline to shore, slipstream 50 million to 100 million off of Lisa and supply onshore, clean power plant that the government will build. Beyond that, very long-term, in terms of LNG or anything like that, that's way down the road. We are focused on optimizing the development plan to move those oily developments forward. And as John said, we have clear visibility to 6, and the seventh is likely just around the corner. So it'll be an oily boat as well. Great. Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Roger Read", "section_number": 49, "uuid": "e91b31b5-165b-482e-b9f4-485956557933", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Wells Fargo"}

section.text: Good morning, everyone. John Hess, while you're on the subject of oil markets, could you give an update and outlook for Libya, please? Thank you.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Sankey", "section_number": 51, "uuid": "40e5a3b1-1aa1-489b-a3a2-f43e04ab9900", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Sankey Research"}

section.text: Paul, thanks for the easy question. Look, Libya is still having political unrest, political divide between the East and the West. And there are some encouraging signs that they're going to start coming together for the leadership of the country, but it would be premature for me to comment further on that. We are still hopeful that we're going to be able to conclude our sale of our assets there to Total and ConocoPhillips, but it needs leadership approval from the government, and that's a work in progress.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 52, "uuid": "51139181-4f7a-4e6d-9a2d-51c2754f5713", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Understood. Another thing which is a little bit inside baseball, but maybe an opportunity for you to talk about a big theme is the asset retirement obligations that you had in the quarter. Is that a sort of a one-and-done payment that you're making in the Gulf of Mexico? Is there an outlook there for more of the same or is that sort of putting an end to it. And could you comment on the overall attractiveness and position in the Gulf of Mexico and your plans there? We don't hear you talking much about it, but obviously we're aware you've got a pretty good position. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Sankey", "section_number": 53, "uuid": "a326034a-ede7-44fb-a7d0-7a47096c767d", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Sankey Research"}

section.text: So, I'll start with the asset retirement obligations and then I'll hand it over to Greg for the Gulf. So the asset retirement obligations that we had -- that we took the charge on this quarter, it was basically for non-producing properties that we just updated our estimates on, on those wells that are being abandoned. And this is really kind of near-term wells that we're going to be working on. So, that, yes, it's more of a one-time.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "8ade7cb0-60ca-4e5b-a329-d16f6493eb2b", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Now, overall, like we've got a lot of wells that will come to be abandoned, but over the long-term, and the change in the estimate for all those wells were not that much, but what happens from an accounting standpoint is when they're producing, you increase the liability, increase the asset.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "8ade7cb0-60ca-4e5b-a329-d16f6493eb2b", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: So, again, I would say you don't have to think about it more as a recurring type thing. This is kind of a one-off for these non-producing properties that we have in the near-term.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 3, "speaker": "John P. Rielly", "section_number": 54, "uuid": "8ade7cb0-60ca-4e5b-a329-d16f6493eb2b", "speaker_title": "Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Sankey", "section_number": 55, "uuid": "eeb59259-bdc5-4543-832b-8968255d0416", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Sankey Research"}

section.text: And, Paul, let me talk about kind of where we're headed in the Gulf. So, as you kind of intimated, the Gulf of Mexico remains as a really important cash engine and platform for growth for us, and so our objective is to sustain or grow production there through both tiebacks and hub-class exploration opportunities. So we've been selectively rebuilding our Gulf of Mexico portfolio, as you know, in the last six years, and we've acquired more than 60 new lease blocks and have a really good balance of both types of opportunities.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "aa231851-8e6a-40cf-afcf-fa8e7bd3552b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: So, I think a good planning assumption is that we would drill two wells per year for the next several years, and then if we kind of hone in on 2023, we're still finalizing the program, but we're seeing the potential next year for two tiebacks and one hub-class exploration opportunity based upon the success of our Huron well this year, and also in most of these prospects that I talked about, our partners are Shell and Chevron. So, we're in with a very good partnership in the Gulf.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 56, "uuid": "aa231851-8e6a-40cf-afcf-fa8e7bd3552b", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Got it. And, I'll ask a leading question. Has government policy made the difference to the way you've lived through to the Gulf of Mexico? And I'll leave it there. Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Sankey", "section_number": 57, "uuid": "6af64655-0354-44a9-98d3-65b0ce64a23e", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Sankey Research"}

section.text: No, it hasn't.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 58, "uuid": "5492c1da-b6f9-4d47-8580-61a39d6d7258", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Thanks.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Paul Sankey", "section_number": 59, "uuid": "ccc870f1-fb9d-4bf5-96cc-23ce75cfbf81", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Sankey Research"}

section.text: Hey, good morning. Thanks for the color on the Uaru development. You mentioned 250,000 a day, I'd seen third-party reports that 275,000 a day, and it sort of begs the question given that standard fall, how large could you get in terms of what's the capacity limit for an FPSO of that class?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bob Brackett", "section_number": 61, "uuid": "06c0a456-caa6-43c5-9829-993966b30885", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bernstein"}

section.text: Thanks, Bob. I think the opportunity to kind of debottleneck is going to be bespoke. So, it's going to be vessel by vessel now. You'll recall, we debottlenecked Phase 1. It went from 120,000 to 140,000. Based on the early production performance of Phase 2, it looks likely that we will probably have some debottlenecking potential there. As these well -- as these vessels come on, based upon the early production history, call it first year or so, that is when you'll decide where you pinch points are and how much debottlenecking capability there is on each vessel. So, it's going to be bespoke, and we'll just have to wait and see what that early production data shows.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 62, "uuid": "fbbbeb79-2803-45db-8720-e2c7876eedb4", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: In terms of maximum capacity, any guess?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bob Brackett", "section_number": 63, "uuid": "187f9ff0-fb7c-4218-8484-24e3e3314ef2", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bernstein"}

section.text: Well, I think 10% to 15% is kind of what would be typical. If you look at Phase 1, and maybe potentially Phase 2. 275,000, I don't know. I just don't know. Again, every vessel is going to be different and I think it'd be premature to throw out numbers like that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 64, "uuid": "a6387451-bec0-488f-b56a-fb68a478a4b8", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: And Bob, obviously, this is all subject to government approval. We're going to be putting our plan of development in, and assuming something in the range, conceptually, of 250,000 a day, is probably a good planning assumption, but again, it's subject to government approval.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 65, "uuid": "de1508c8-8540-4d2d-aa25-2dd521866dfb", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Very clear. A follow-up then, this has been your biggest year of sort of deeper Santonian exploration in Guyana. Any update on progress and learnings thoughts about the Santonian?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bob Brackett", "section_number": 66, "uuid": "b8659cd4-a836-420f-bbcf-ed4253345657", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bernstein"}

section.text: Well, I think the results speak for themselves. I mean the deep is very promising. And I think we will continue, as I said in my opening remarks, we will continue to really understand the deep potential with many of the wells that we're going to be drilling in the fourth quarter. Fangtooth Southeast, for example, located 8 miles southeast of Fangtooth is going to spud, and then that -- Fangtooth is a very high quality, very large reservoir system, and putting another well 8 miles southeast of there will tell us a lot. So, I am very optimistic about the deep.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 67, "uuid": "e0428302-ea0c-4f3b-8e34-2e2537366f4a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: And there are a number of other prospects that we had a recent review on. One's called Lancet Fish, which is...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 68, "uuid": "ca40d534-026e-4b78-bd6e-4bf685ef747e", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Yes...
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 69, "uuid": "1d2940f5-8974-4851-b4e1-7bb7898dbc61", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: East of Fangtooth. Then we have Fish-1 and Fish-2 that are reasonable distance to the west and northwest of Fangtooth. So, there's a lot of prospectivity to come. As we get more success in finding these deeper horizons, our ability to correlate the seismic new prospects are lighting up. So there's a lot more upside that Greg is talking about that hopefully in the next six months, we'll be able to give updates on.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "John B. Hess", "section_number": 70, "uuid": "337fcf0a-e15a-471b-be33-7038bdf27232", "speaker_title": "Chief Executive Officer at Hess"}

section.text: And Bob, just to remind you that the Fish-1 is 62 miles northwest of Liza-1. So, that gives you an idea of the extent of some of these deep reservoir systems what we see, and then of course, Lancet Fish is tucked close to Lisa. It's about 3 miles West of the Lisa-3 well, and it's targeting deep sands that underlie that Lisa complex.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 71, "uuid": "11245dad-98e9-4c5d-acc6-4175bc086048", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Thanks for that.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Bob Brackett", "section_number": 72, "uuid": "4aff39b5-1e9c-4c9a-ba7e-050c883588ad", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Bernstein"}

section.text: Hi, good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noel Parks", "section_number": 74, "uuid": "adbdd8b7-cf92-445b-8d07-a5e2c9ea8fac", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Touhy Brothers"}

section.text: Good morning.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 75, "uuid": "4228399a-d837-4398-becc-4f7a11c88d9a", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: I was wondering, at Banjo, if you could just talk a bit about how the results there sort of maybe ripple through your analysis. I'm thinking maybe the seismic interpretation or if there is anything else you learned about beyond just the aerial extent of the resource there?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noel Parks", "section_number": 76, "uuid": "96c38d8f-c255-4866-bdbd-f1c5c86e240a", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Touhy Brothers"}

section.text: Noel, look, again, I think we already talked about the significance of Banjo. I think that the question is really about the inboard oil play. And recall, we've had for discoveries in this area, Barreleye, Seabob, Yarrow, Lucanani which all had significant amounts of oil pay. Banjo was the westernmost well. So, in that area, it was a bit of an out step, if you will, from the fairway. We've got a bunch more wells to drill in that area. So, I don't think you should read anything negative into the Banjo result at all.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 77, "uuid": "e99561d9-9f01-4de9-9a47-92bb3199c3e3", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Okay. Fair enough. And I just wanted to turn to the Bakken for a minute and Just wondering if you had any updated thoughts on our experience with recompletions up there? If I recall, you had done some work going back to some of the older vintage wells were done sort of at the the original much lighter completions out there. And so -- and if you have been doing anything out there, what the potential -- I guess about what the returns might look like for sort of work?
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noel Parks", "section_number": 78, "uuid": "f988263b-dce8-4c57-b50e-e60730f58b97", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Touhy Brothers"}

section.text: Well, the -- we have been doing a number of refracs, and the results have been very good. And in some cases, the wells -- the IP rates that we're seeing are as good as some of the new wells, and that's not surprising because these were kind of vintage 001 completions. We have several hundred wells that we could refrac, and we will fit them in our program as we go forward.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 79, "uuid": "47551307-a0ec-4466-be7c-bfbf7e815f3d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: One of the advantages of the refrac program is it allows you more continuity with the frac crew. So we've been sort of dovetailing some refracs into our program just to maintain continuity of a second frac crew. So you'll see more of that activity next year. But so far so good, the results are good, and the returns are very good because all the infrastructure are already there, the well's there.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 2, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 79, "uuid": "47551307-a0ec-4466-be7c-bfbf7e815f3d", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

section.text: Okay. Thanks a lot.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Noel Parks", "section_number": 80, "uuid": "613642ec-831f-4ab8-a0a9-1b8f15a3f7f9", "speaker_title": "Analyst at Touhy Brothers"}

section.text: Yeah.
section.metadata_json: {"paragraph_number": 1, "speaker": "Gregory P. Hill", "section_number": 81, "uuid": "73cb78b9-5c3d-4b4e-ad3b-23ad2ca1ec29", "speaker_title": "President and Chief Operating Officer at Hess"}

title: Q&A for HES (Hess) on 10/26/22 10:00 AM ET
